scenarios.title: Nighttime Earthquake at Home
scenarios.description: It's 2:13 AM. You're sleeping in your second-floor apartment in Bangkok when a 6.8 magnitude earthquake begins. The shaking is strong and getting stronger. Your bed is moving, and you can hear things falling in other rooms.

choices.text: Stay in bed and cover head with pillow
choices.explanation: Correct! Drop, Cover, and Hold On. In bed, stay there, cover your head and neck with a pillow, and hold on.

choices.text: Jump up and run outside immediately
choices.explanation: Dangerous! Running during shaking increases injury risk. Most injuries occur when people try to move during an earthquake.
Outdated advice! Doorways are not safer than other parts of the building. Drop, Cover, and Hold On is better.

scenarios.follow_up: What should you do after the shaking stops?

follow_up_choices.text: Check for injuries and hazards before moving
follow_up_choices.explanation: Correct! Check yourself and others for injuries. Look for hazards like gas leaks, broken glass, or structural damage.

follow_up_choices.text: Rush outside immediately to check the building
follow_up_choices.explanation: Wait! Check for hazards first. Broken glass, debris, or aftershocks could cause injury.

scenarios.title: Earthquake at the Office
scenarios.description: You're working at your desk on the 15th floor of an office building in Yangon when a strong earthquake hits. Your computer monitor is shaking, and colleagues are shouting. The building is swaying noticeably.

choices.text: Drop under your desk and hold on
choices.explanation: Correct! Drop, Cover, and Hold On. Your desk provides protection from falling objects.

choices.text: Head for the elevator to get down quickly
choices.explanation: Never use elevators during an earthquake! They may malfunction or stop between floors.
Don't run during shaking! You could fall or be hit by falling objects. Take cover first.

scenarios.follow_up: The shaking has stopped. What's your next priority?

follow_up_choices.text: Follow the building's evacuation plan calmly
follow_up_choices.explanation: Correct! Use stairs, not elevators. Follow evacuation routes and help others if possible.
Time is critical! Don't waste time on belongings. Focus on safe evacuation.

scenarios.title: Earthquake in Shopping Mall
scenarios.description: You're shopping at a busy mall in Bangkok when a moderate earthquake begins. People start screaming and running. You're near a large window display, and items are falling from shelves nearby.

choices.text: Drop to the ground and cover your head
choices.explanation: Correct! Protect yourself from falling objects. Stay away from windows and displays.

choices.text: Follow the crowd toward the exit
choices.explanation: Dangerous! Crowds can cause stampedes. Take cover first, then evacuate calmly when shaking stops.
Walls can have hanging objects or windows. Better to drop and cover on the ground.

scenarios.follow_up: After the shaking stops, how do you evacuate?

follow_up_choices.text: Walk calmly to the nearest exit, avoiding elevators
follow_up_choices.explanation: Correct! Stay calm, use stairs, and be aware of aftershocks.

follow_up_choices.text: Help anyone who has fallen or is injured
follow_up_choices.explanation: Good! Help others if you can do so safely, but don't put yourself at risk.

scenarios.title: Earthquake During Class
scenarios.description: You're a teacher in a classroom with 25 students when an earthquake starts. The children are looking to you for guidance. Books are falling from shelves and the lights are swaying.

choices.text: Shout 'Drop, Cover, Hold On!' and demonstrate
choices.explanation: Excellent! Lead by example. Clear, calm directions help prevent panic.

choices.text: Tell students to line up in the doorway
choices.explanation: Outdated and dangerous! Doorways aren't safer, and crowding causes problems.
Don't move during shaking! Take cover first, then evacuate when it's safe.

scenarios.follow_up: The shaking has stopped. How do you handle evacuation?

follow_up_choices.text: Lead an organized evacuation to the designated assembly area
follow_up_choices.explanation: Perfect! Follow school procedures, keep students together, and account for everyone.

follow_up_choices.text: Let students go home to their families
follow_up_choices.explanation: Don't! Keep students safe until parents can pick them up or authorities give all-clear.

scenarios.title: Earthquake While Driving
scenarios.description: You're driving on a busy street in Bangkok when you feel your car shaking. At first you think it's a tire problem, but then you see other cars stopping and people getting out. You realize it's an earthquake.

choices.text: Pull over safely away from buildings and power lines
choices.explanation: Correct! Stop in a safe location and stay in your vehicle until shaking stops.

choices.text: Speed up to get away from the earthquake zone
choices.explanation: Dangerous! You can't outrun an earthquake, and speeding during shaking causes accidents.

choices.text: Stop under the nearest overpass for protection
choices.explanation: Never stop under overpasses! They can collapse. Find an open area instead.

scenarios.follow_up: You've stopped safely. What do you do next?

follow_up_choices.text: Stay in the car with seatbelt on until shaking stops
follow_up_choices.explanation: Correct! Your car protects you from falling debris. Don't get out during shaking.

follow_up_choices.text: Get out of the car immediately
follow_up_choices.explanation: Stay in your car! It provides protection from falling objects and debris.

excellent.message: Excellent earthquake response! You demonstrated proper safety knowledge and made decisions that would protect lives. You're well-prepared for earthquake emergencies.

good.message: Good earthquake response! You made mostly safe choices. Review the feedback to improve your preparedness even further.

needs_improvement.message: Your response needs improvement. Study earthquake safety guidelines and practice Drop, Cover, and Hold On. Consider taking a first aid course.

dangerous.message: Your responses could be dangerous in a real earthquake. Please study proper earthquake safety procedures immediately and consider attending a disaster preparedness workshop.
